content:
ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-089-015 atï hpe senï tahkene pïtai tahkene m-ene-0-n pïtai rë pïtai boota senï
‘What is that, maybe, a shoe maybe, do you see, it's really a shoe, a shoe, it's a boot.’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-089-032 **mëe** nï-të-0-n **okomo** **awekïï** ton irë apo
‘they went, the bees, like that.’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-089-037 irëme **mëe** **kaikui** sokanme E.RD-n-ee-ja-n 0-eeka-0 se
‘then this one, the dog, stood up, (he) wanted to bite it (= the beehive).’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-091-045 oota 0-ene-0 marë tï-w-ënaanuu-se **wewe** **serë** **mono** t-oota-ke t-0-ee-se
‘He climbed up to see the hole, this big tree had a hole.  ’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-091-047 irë-npë pëe **wewe** **t-oota-ke-n** pëe t-V:-e-pataka-e jeepurutu
‘Then from the tree with a hole came an owl.’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-093-094 mëe ja tï-tomeka-e 0-entu-pisi ja përëru tï-tomeka-e
‘He took it, his little owner took the frog’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-033-075 Ape ma kii-ponoo-ja-ti **Përëpërëwa** **kï-tamu-V:** kon
‘(Ape) Well, we are telling (the story of) Përëpërëwa our ancestor,  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-033-077 Ape i-w-ëtï-rï-0-hpë **nërë** **kï-tamu-V:** kon Përëpërëwa
‘(Ape) he is the one who made himself, our ancestor, Përëpërëwa.  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-041-269 Ape n-ee-ja-n **mono** **kanawa** tï-V:-ka-e irë hkaasan kura-no
‘(Ape) 'A big canoe is coming', (she) said, 'that is good (= i.e. not the one you have),'’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-041-270 Ape sen n-ai **tuna** **mono** juuwë i-V:-të-0-n mahtao n-e-manaka-0-n tï-V:-ka-e
‘(Ape) 'This one is... when it's on a big river, it turns,' (she) said.’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-043-278 Ape wëën **mëërë** t-V:-etainka-e **tamutupë**
‘(Ape) /wëën/... that one ran, the old man (= i.e. Përëpërëwa).  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-045-323 Ape ëwë 0-aamuurë-too me **mëërë** ja **kaikë** ja
‘(Ape) (They were) later to be harassed by the fox.’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-045-324 Ape nërë ja t-ënë-too me **mëërë** **wëri-npë**
‘(Ape) The woman (is to) be eaten by him.’

ex:dados-07-frog-story-marciano-p-093-096 **mëesamo** inëërë **përëru** ton tï-w-ët-akaa-se ken
‘It's them, the frogs, they're forming a line,  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-037-179 Ape nka anpo n-a V:-akoron tï-V:-ka-e **nërë** rë **tamutupë** anpo n-a V:-akoron
‘(Ape) 'So, where is your companion?' (he) said, he, the old man, 'where is your companion?'’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-043-304 Ape oh-kë tï-V:-ka-e oh-kë nari ke ta eh-kë ët-amïï-sewa **serë** **wëitapi** tï-V:-ka-e
‘(Ape) 'Come,' (she) said, 'come, don't be afraid, this won't break/snap, the hammock,' (she) said.  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-047-354 Ape eeke n-ai **mëe** **ji-pïtï** tï-V:-ka-e sera atïtoome n-ai mïra i-jomi-rï tï-V:-ka-e
‘(Ape) 'How is my wife?' (= 'What's with her?') he said, like this, 'why is her talk like that?' (= 'why is she talking funny?'), he said.  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-047-363 Ape sera taa san n-ai ji-pïtï anpo n-ai mëe i-nmuku-ru mëesan n-ai i-japo taike
‘(Ape) 'they are not like this, my wife, where is she, this one, her son, they aren't like this' ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-047-374 Ape irë mao t-ënepiita-e mëërë ja t-urë-e werekeru ja
‘(Ape) Then he became tired of it, and that one talked to him, werekeru.’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-049-387 Ape mëe 0-inë-0 ë-nmuku-0 ë-enuuma-ne npa tï-V:-ka-e mërë i-nnapï 0-apëh-kë irëme tï-rë-e i-:ja toron
‘(Ape) 'Leave this one here, your son, he would disturb you,' he said, 'get that, his food', then, he put it (down), /toron/.’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-049-392 Ape mëërë se man-a-n tï-V:-ka-e **tarïpi** se man-a-n **mëërë** tï-V:-ka-e
‘(Ape) 'Do you want that one?' he said, 'do you want some monkey, that one?' he said.  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-049-415 Ape **mëe** marë **i-nmuku-hpë** i-japo ro pa tï-V:-ka-e
‘(Ape) 'And this one also, my son, just like her (he was killed),' he said.  ’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-051-442 Ape irëme aerë-n me tï-V:-të-e mono tuna t-0-ee-se n-ka-0-n to tï-ponopï-0
‘(Ape) Then he really went, the river was high, they say.’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-051-443 Ape t-0-ee-se tuna mono t-0-ee-se irë mao rë waraku 0-eeku mono mono tuna t-0-ee-se ka-to tï-ponopï-0 serë
‘(Ape) the river had become big, at that time, Waraku's river was big, the river had risen, this is the telling,’

ex:dados-09-kereramake-p-053-455 Ape tïwërë-no ro i-juuwë t-0-ee-se mërë toron
‘(Ape) Another one was on top of it, /toro/,’

‘Well... I finally grew up, I became a young man.  ’

‘'well, I want this woman,' I said,  ’

ex:mini-disc-lsmtam13set0001-marciano-little-introduction-003 ma **ji-jomi-V:** tae rë j-eka-0 **tarëno** tae n-ai Minausi irë apo m-eta-0
‘Well, in my own language my name, in (the language of the) Tiriyó, it is, Minausi, like this. OK? (= Did you hear?).  ’

ex:mini-disc-lsmtam13set0001-marciano-little-introduction-004 irëme anja oroko me n-ai menjaarë ët-akëërë **mëe** marë **Sesu** marë
‘So we're now working together,’

ex:mini-disc-lsmtam13set0001-marciano-little-introduction-005 **serë** pë **panpira** pë anja n-ai oroko me m-eta-0 irë apo
‘We're now working about this, about this book/paper (= i.e. we're writing something). Did you hear? That's it.  ’

ex:minidisc-xxx-mukusa-nasau-sep-2000-004 Nasau w-epekatï-0 irë pananakiri ton 0-otï këpëewa k-otï komo se rëkene re w-ei-0 irë se w-ei-0
‘(Nasau) I've already sold/given it as meat for the foreigners, but I want (another cow) for our food, that's what I want.’

ex:minidisc-xxx-oiapoque-pona-iitetoponpe-sep-2000-020 ëwë **serë** **0-akoron** **tao** mono me n-ëturu-ta-n tarëno
‘'Later the other one like this (= meeting), the Tiriyó/Indians will talk a lot.'’

ex:minidisc-xxx-oiapoque-pona-iitetoponpe-sep-2000-039 … mararija 0-epi ton pë tïwërë-no ro kïn-ëturu tï-pata-V: pë
‘About malaria medicine(s), another (person) talked, about his/her own village,  ’

‘Well, then I came, along the creeks/tribuaries, our old river... what-do-you-call-it, the Kuruni (Coeroeni).  ’

‘This little one is sleeping, this is the little man (= boy), this is him, do you see?  ’

‘The arrows (were) ones that were very many.’

‘My late father was the one, the one who said it thus.’

‘He (is) the one who went like that.’

‘"Make this, my older brother's seat," said his wife.’

ex:derbyshire-1965-p-064-the-wives-of-mawarye-and-woxka-121 mosonï ha Woxka k-he-txe

‘Marking change of subject, "Woxka," he said to him, to his brother.’

‘He was sexually intercoursing her there, beside the river, beside the big lake.’

‘The anaconda took Woxka away.’

‘It seems that they will be forgetting good stories’

‘By she the old woman’
